title: Leading law expert says police ban on Extinction Rebellion probably ‘unlawful’
text:
Police officers working today at Vauxhall Gardens, where protesters have been asked to leave (Picture: AFP)

One of the country’s leading experts on human rights and protest has said there is a ‘very good chance’ that the Metropolitan Police’s decision to ban all Extinction Rebellion (XR) protests across London is ‘unlawful’.

Professor David Mead, who specialises in UK Human Rights Law at the University of East Anglia, suggested the move could contradict both European and British law.

He said: ‘I think there is a very good chance that a court would conclude that the Met’s decision to impose a condition bringing to an end the XR protests in London would be unlawful.

‘If it were seen as one bringing to an end all XR protests, then I think it would be unlawful as European human rights law, and our own Human Rights Act, require such decisions to be proportionate. That means narrowly tailored to address an identifiable problem.’

Advertisement

Advertisement

His comments follow the Met’s move to ban any assembly linked to the XR ‘Autumn Uprising’ under Section 14 of the Public Order Act, from 9pm last night.

Officers started removing the environmental group out of Trafalgar Square yesterday after more than a week of disruption, with more protesters leaving the Vauxhall Gardens site today.

Police officers stand on near patches of light coloured grass, marking the ground where activists’ tents used to be at Vauxhall Gardens (Picture: AFP)

Activists carry their belongings away from the site – but many say other items have been seized (Picture: AFP)

The Shadow Home Secretary, Diane Abbott, and the Mayor of London, Sadiq Khan, have already raised concerns about the decision, which has drawn widespread criticism.

In a statement, the Met’s Deputy Assistant Commissioner Laurence Taylor justified the stringent conditions because of ‘continued breaches of the section 14 condition previously implemented, and ongoing serious disruption to the community.’

She continued: ‘Yesterday, protesters targeted areas in the City of London, causing further disruption to people and businesses in London’s financial district.

‘Since the beginning of this operation officers have been working hard to keep London moving.

‘The policing operation continues, and we will continue to take action against anyone engaged in unlawful protests at locations targeted by Extinction Rebellion.’

Ex-boxer Ricky Hatton gives Paul Gascoigne character reference in court

But Professor Mead, a former solicitor and an expert on protest, put further doubt on the legitimacy of the move, which follows 1,457 arrests (as of 8.45am this morning) since protests began.

Advertisement

Advertisement

He continued: ‘There are I think other legal issues that the Met would have to overcome, largely relating to the certainty of the target assembly. Human rights law requires that where restrictions are imposed, then protesters are entitled to know with sufficient certainty if they are affected. I am not sure that’s the case here.

‘While it might (but quite possibly not) be lawful to bring this one specific assembly to an end by imposing a condition, it cannot lawfully be used to impose an effective ban on all assemblies in London, which on one reading the notice seeks to.’

He added that decisions involving the Home Secretary are ‘far more politically accountable’.

Legal expert Professor Mead (Picture: David Mead)

XR demonstrators gather their belongings from Vauxhall Gardens (Picture: AFP)

This is the ninth day of demonstrations by the climate change action group (Picture: AFP)

The Home Office said using Section 14 was an operational decision for the police.

A spokesperson added: ‘The right to protest peacefully is a long-standing tradition in this country and a vital foundation of our democracy. It is also essential that people can go about their daily business without disruption.’

Labelling the ruling ‘completely ludicrous and extremely alarming’, Kevin Blowe, a Coordinator of the Network for Police Monitoring (Netpol), said: ‘Normally, banning a protest in its entirety in London requires the approval of the Home Secretary, but is rare and undoubtedly controversial.

Advertisement

‘The police are trying to side-step this by using their wide-ranging powers in a way that we believe is unreasonable, disproportionate and therefore a breach of rights to freedom of assembly and expression protected by the European Convention on Human Rights.’

He added: ‘If Netpol decided to stand outside New Scotland Yard today with a banner saying “protect our rights to protest”, it is likely nothing would happen to us. If, however, individuals came and stood with us displaying any item that has Extinction Rebellion’s name or branding on it, they would very likely face arrest.’

Dr Michelle Farrell, a Senior Lecturer in Law at the University of Liverpool, said the police action ‘almost certainly fails to meet the legal requirements of necessity and proportionality, obligations that the police must comply with under the Human Rights Act and European Convention on Human Rights’.

She added: ‘The police have failed to establish a legitimate aim for imposing this section 14 order; getting “London moving again” does not cut the mustard legally speaking.

‘The police have not shown in any credible way how the XR Autumn Uprising as a whole raises a general risk of serious public disorder or serious disruption to the life of the community, and, moreover, they have not shown why this general ban is necessary rather than more restrictive targeted measures.’

Advertisement

The Met were asked to respond to Professor Mead’s comments.

description: Professor David Mead says Metropolitan Police's ban of Extinction Rebellion protesters in London under Section 14 likely to be unlawful.
